text: This is my first üó∫Ô∏è traveling post so go easy on me. This is my experience.

description: public bus ‚Ññ116
text: 1. **Private taxi** is the most expensive and the most boring type of transport. It costs $20 - $50 (depends on your bargain skills) from one to another part of the island. There is usually AC there.
2. **Public bus** is absolutely ordinary transport. It costs $1 from one to another part of the island. There is usually no AC there and sometimes a lot of people.

description: dala dala ‚Ññ116
text: 3. **Dala dala** is the local minibus share taxis. The craziest and the most fun way to explore the island. It's always overcrowded and accelerates to unsafety speeds. Every time you think it's completely full they add more people and baggage there. Some baggage is on the roof but another part is inside. Also, the roof is pretty low so you hit it with your head many times. It's really unforgettable experience.
Dala dala inside:

description: dala dala ‚Ññ116
text: The conductor here can hang on the back of the car only with his neck, teach Swahili people inside, invite people outside to join the trip, manage free space inside and use his cellphone at the same time! The true multitasking.

description: ü¶á bats inside the Mangapwani coral cave
text: **Mangapwani Coral Cave** is a large natural cavern with a freshwater pool that was used as a source of üö∞ drinking water for local people and to hold the slaves before the trade. It's dark and slippery and holds many bats inside. Somewhere it's very narrow and you need climbing up in the end.

text: There were a lot of people who spoke different languages in the dark without the toilet and the future. The slave trade was really popular here. The Zanzibar means the land of the blacks.

description: Mangapwani coral cave ‚ÑπÔ∏è info stand
text: It's interesting that people who accepted Islam stopped being slaves here.

description: snorkeling
text: There are many small islands over the Unguja to visit. Some of them are so small that you can visit them only if the water is low, otherwise, it will be under the water. Snorkeling is popular among these islands. But there are some bigger islands to visit.

**Kwale Island** is famous because of the Baobab Tree - the popular symbol of Africa. Usually, the way here is combined with other small islands, ü§ø snorkeling, the mangrove lagoon, and seafood dinner.

Changu Island
text: **Changu Island** (aka Prison Island) is the island close to **Stone Town**. You can find the old prison (that was never actually used as a prison) and üê¢ giant tortoises here. The tortoises are really impressive. They look like ü§ñ massive robots, move so slowly. In 1919 the British governor of Seychelles sent a gift of four Aldabra giant tortoises to Changuu. More tortoises continue to be brought to the island from other locations for conservation. Visitors are able to observe and to feed the tortoises.
The simples way to visit Changu Island is üõ•Ô∏è the boat from the Stone Town.

description: airport
text: The island has hakuna matata life pace. Sometimes it looks like the majority of local people can hurry only when they drive Dala dala) The flight from the island was postponed for 1.5 hours during the giant lines.

It's so unusual to be in such a crowd in coronavirus time. But for the country where around 1.5 million people have HIV/AIDS, where the malaria and tuberculosis are some of the most popular causes of üíÄ mortality... Maybe, it's not the biggest problem here.

from Brest to Naliboki forest and back
text: Winter is not the best time for traveling, but you can see places underneath with a completely different perspective. So, here is our plan:
- üü¢ Green marks - nature points
- üîµ Blue marks - historical points
- ‚ö´ Grey marks - missed points (next time)

description: from Brest to Naliboki forest
the road to Navahrudak castle ruins
text: Navahrudak is a cozy town on the hills with üè∞ castle ruins. It is a possible first capital of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania.

description: Navahrudak castle ruins
text: The castle in Navahrudak was one of the key strongholds of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania.

description: the view from the Navahrudak castle hill to Transfiguration Roman Catholic Church
text: The ‚õ™ Roman Catholic Transfiguration Church (1712‚Äì23, includes surviving chapels of an older gothic building), where Adam Mickiewicz was baptised.

description: the view from the Navahrudak castle hill
text: According to ‚õèÔ∏è archaeological research conducted in Navahrudak in the 1960s, the settlement on the territory of modern Navahrudak arose at the end of the 10th century, and the fortifications by the middle of the 11th century.

description: the Lubcha barbican outside
text: Lubcha castle was a Radziwi≈Ç≈Ç family residential castle on the left bank of the Neman river at Lubcha town.

description: the Neman river
text: The castle was built in 1581 as a fortified residence of Jan Kiszka, a powerful Calvinist magnate. It had timber walls, a single stone tower, and was surrounded by moats on three sides, the fourth side protected by the river.

description: the Lubcha barbican inside
text: Lubcha later passed to Janusz Radziwi≈Ç≈Ç, who expanded the castle by adding three stone towers.

description: the palace was remodeled into a school
text: In 1655 it was taken and devastated by the rebellious Cossacks under Ivan Zolotarenko.

Only the barbican and one other tower were left standing after the Cossack incursion. The deserted estate changed owners several times, remaining untenanted until the mid-19th century, when a Gothic Revival palace was built on the grounds.
The Lubcha estate suffered much damage during both world wars. The palace was reduced to a shell in 1914 and was remodeled into a üè´ school building by the Soviets in 1947.
In the early 21st century, some of the üß± castle walls were rebuilt by a team of volunteers.

description: a bed under the roof
text: This cozy place was the final destination. It's a small 4-persons max guest house with a beautiful view of the Naliboki forest.

description: warm stove
text: With a warm stove this ü•∂ cold winter.

description: Vjendzhanyja prysmaki and Naliboki forest
text: And ü•ì delicious treats "Vjendzhanyja prysmaki" after long way.

description: Playing Love Letter
text: Have you tried ale with juniper before? I haven't, until this trip. And it's one of the tastiest ale I have ever tried!
What can create even better atmosphere? Yes, üé≤ board games.

description: from Naliboki Forest to Brest
Dzyarzhynskaya hara is 345 meters above the sea level
text: There is nothing special here. Just ‚õ∞Ô∏è the highest point in Belarus. It is 345 meters (1,130 ft) above sea level and is located west of Minsk, near Dzyarzhynsk, in the village Skirmuntava.

description: Mir castle outside
text: Mir castle probably is one of the two most popular historical places in Belarus.

description: Mir castle tower
text: Built at the beginning of the 16th century by a tycoon, the castle became the first private property castle on the lands of Belarus.

description: Mir castle courtyard
text: Since 1568, the castle was owned by the Radziwi≈Ç≈Ç family (until 1828), then the Wittgensteins (until 1891). The last owners of the castle were the princes Svyatopolk-Mirsky (until 1939), after which, with the advent of the Soviets, the castle became state property.
Mir castle is the most eastern Gothic building, as well as the largest and only non-cult object of the few surviving examples of the original Belarusian Gothic.

description: Nesvizh castle outside the moat
Nesvizh castle courtyard
text: It was built in the 16th and 17th centuries and maintained by the Radziwi≈Ç≈Ç family until 1939.

description: the Hrusauka manor outside
the Hrusauka manor rooms
text: This estate belonged to the Rejtan family. On 20 August 1742, Tadeusz Rejtan was born here. Rejtan is remembered for a dramatic gesture he made in September 1773, as a deputy of the Partition Sejm. There, Rejtan tried to prevent the legalization of the first partition of Poland, a scene that has been immortalized in the painting Rejtan by Jan Matejko:
> Kill me, do not kill the Fatherland!

description: the Hrusauka manor inside
text: Tadeusz Rejtan never married. He spent the rest of his days in a small estate at Hrusz√≥wka, where he died on 8 August 1780. His mental health had deteriorated; according to some due to distress with the loss of a part of his homeland.

description: the Hrusauka manor ceiling
text: He is said to have been escorted by his brothers from Warsaw on 19 March 1775 after he had a fit, and was locked in a small family's mansion which he would never leave up till his death.

description: the Hrusauka manor ceiling
text: Eventually, he committed suicide, cutting himself with glass (most detailed accounts say he swallowed it, to prevent being taken by pursuing Russian soldiers). His exact place of burial is unknown, and exhumation in Hrusz√≥wka in 1930 failed to conclusively find his grave.

description: a stone with Kastus Kalinowski portrait
text: Kastus Kalinowski (1838‚Äì1864), was one of the leaders of Lithuanian and Belarusian national revival and the leader of the January Uprising in the lands of the former Grand Duchy of Lithuania.

description: a stone with memorial plaque and inscription in Belarusian was erected in 1990
text: It began on 22 January 1863 and continued until the last insurgents were captured by the Russian forces in 1864. It was the longest insurgency in post-partition Poland.

description: memorial chapel was built in 1933 in honor of the Kalinowski rebels
text: After the battle, the bodies of the fighters were ü™¶ buried in two mass graves on opposite sides of the road near the forest.

description: the view from the Narikala Fortress in Tbilisi
text: Summer is a good time for a vacation. Sometimes it's not many options to go to. In summer 2021, üá¨üá™ **Georgia** was one of the not many options for me. Maybe, that's why it was a little bit underrated. But now I want to return there because there are too many interesting places to see during one ‚úàÔ∏è trip.
This page is bigger than it should be, but I can't remove any more photos from it. Sorry for that.

But in two words: Jason and the Argonauts from üá¨üá∑ **Greece** were looking for Golden Fleece here. Medea lived here fell in love with Jason killed her own brother and helped Jason to find it and run away from here with him. But Jason decided to marries another woman later Medea killed her and her own children from Jason and disappeared (‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçüî• burn herself).

text: Let's go to üáπüá∑ **Turkish** desserts. üáπüá∑ **Turkey** is not far from here so there are common desserts in the countries around the Black sea.
Pohlava (or Baklava - don't confuse with Balaclava!) is a layered pastry dessert made of filo pastry, filled with chopped nuts, and sweetened with syrup or honey. It's really popular here.

text: They still use kvevri (like 8000 years ago) to make wine.
Kvevris are large earthenware vessels used for the fermentation, storage and ageing of traditional Georgian wine.
In 2013, UNESCO added the traditional Georgian method of making wine in kvevris to its list of intangible cultural heritage.

text: A good place for üÖøÔ∏è parking.

description: a fire place in front of the owl house terrace
text: And for gatherings near the üî• fire.

description: a delicious natural lunch from the hosts
text: And for eating. The owners can üßë‚Äçüç≥ cook lunch for you. It can be national cuisine dishes with some products from the forest.

description: a view from the forest tower to the owl house
text: Did you notice the owl in the previous photo? They are everywhere here!
Here is the tower for bird watching and for resting not far from the house.

description: the third floor of the forest tower
text: If you couldn't find any birds it's a peaceful place for chill and üßò meditation or reading anyway.

description: the owl house in front of the Bielavie≈æskaja pu≈°ƒça
text: One more photo of the beautiful üè° house and the forest behind.

description: a bird totem not fat from the owl house
text: You can find even a kind of bird totem here!

description: bicycles in front of the hosts house
text: Here is the house where the owners live. The photo before the way home.

description: a fire place with a smoke
text: But as I mention we returned in autumn. First time we spent a lot of time and efforts for the road and the forest tour. So we missed the fire place gatherings.
The next 4 photos is from the autumn visiting.

description: a barbecue in front of the owl house terrace evening illumination
text: What a pity it's a photo, but not a video. September is a ü¶å deer mating season. At this time males scream in the forest to attract females. And it can be heard clearly in this place. It's a little bit scary in the beginning especially because there is no fence between you and the forest with the deers. But the cozy terrace illumination can calm down everyone.

description: Strelka (Arrow) dog on the terrace of the owl house
text: And the local üêï dog. It came from the wild forest and the owners adopted it.

description: the owl house terrace
text: The wall on the terrace looks like a decoration, but it's natural at the same time.

description: inside the owl house
text: But let's go inside the house.

description: the ows inside the owl house
text: It so cozy because of a large number of a small details. Everything was made with love and looks like it's used not for the guest but for the owners.
It's warm and alive. And I bet nobody can count the number of birds inside. It's everywhere!

description: the bed and the stove
text: You will not cold here (of course, if you go to sleep not far from the stove).

description: a really old, loud, and rare refrigerator Zil Moskva in the owl house
text: And maybe it's better to turn off this nice refrigerator to enjoy the üîá silence.

description: the owl posters and the owl plate inside the owl house
text: Something like "Even [hit] the owl on the stump, even [hit] the stump on the owl - the owl hurts anyway".

description: the books inside the owl house
text: A lot of interesting üìö books everywhere in case you didn't take yours with you.

description: a wild animals (wild boar and others) bath in the forest
text: Let's start with a üõÅ bathroom.

description: a bird murder crime scene in the forest
text: There are a lot of wild animals here. Here is the kitchen of some predator.

description: a roe murder crime scene in the forest
text: And one more. This meal was much bigger than a bird from the previous photo.

description: an old house in the Yuzefin village not far from Zalessie
text: **Yuzefin** is a village not far from **Zalessie**. It's almost extinct and even deeper in the forest.

description: our guide with his dog Strelka (Arrow) in the forest
text: There are so many different and rare birds in these places. In the next photo, our guide is trying to attract the bird with its voice playing from the üì± smartphone.

description: a cranberry in the swamp
text: Nature here is not only forest, but also swamps. Cranberry grows right here.

description: an old royal road in the forest
text: Previously it was a great üëë royal track in this place. You still can walk along here.

description: the result of beavers activity (a barrage building)
text: ü¶´ Beaver is one more local here. Some swamps were destroyed during melioration. Now there are programs to restore it. Beavers work on this problem too.

description: a wild spring forest
text: In spring forest is beautiful.

description: Dikoye (Wild) swamp
text: A nice view of the Dikoye (Wild) swamp - a home for so many birds.

description: the view of Pidurangala Mountain from the Sigiriya Ancient Rock Fortress
text: This trip was planned for early 2020 but then covid-19 happened...

description: the view of Dubai
text: It looks really rich everywhere and the metro without a driver that goes above the ground helps have a quick look at the city.

description: a shark and a pool cleaner in the mall in Dubai
text: The city includes a lot of transparent tunnels with AC and escalators to live there even in summer hot. Like in movies about the future!
The giant aquarium with sharks in a shopping mall is an ordinary thing here.

description: Burj Khalifa in Dubai - the tallest building in the world
text: Apart from everything, the city is popular because of the biggest building in the world (829.8 m).

description: Palm Islands in Dubai from the airplane
text: And the famous palm islands are also here. But I didn't have enough time to look at it not from the airplane.

description: baklawa in the Dubai International Airport in Dubai
text: One more impressive thing there is the airport. It is soooooo colossal. It's like a city inside the city. It can take almost an hour to get from one terminal to another.
What to do there? Right, to taste the east desserts.
